title: The complete works of Robert Burns :
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: out to Berrywell in the evening with Miss Ainslie — how well-bred, how frank, how good she is ! Charming  Rachel ! may thy bosom never be wrung by the evils of this life of sorrows, or by the villainy of this world's sons ! *

title: The complete works of Robert Burns :
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: ■f A young man named Symon Gra>, -xie son of a respected citizen of Dunse^ who was in the practice of stringing rhymes together which he fancied were meritorious, sent packet after packet of his trash to Berrywell, to elicit Bums's opinion of them.

title: The complete works of Robert Burns :
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: — Thursday, [17th], breakfast at Berrywell, f and walk into Dunse to see a famous knife made by a cutler there, and to be presented to an Italian prince.

title: The complete works of Robert Burns :
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: Dine at a country inn, kept by a miller in Barlston,* the birth-place and residence of the celebrated Thomas the Rhymer — saw the ruins of his castle — come to Berrywell.

title: The complete works of Robert Burns :
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: Our poet, in the course of his first winter in Edinburgh, had formed an intimate acquaintance with Robert Ainslie, the son of a substantial farmer at Berrywell, near Dunse, in Berwickshire.

title: The complete poetical and prose works of Robert Burns:
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: Ainslie of Berrywell, the father of his companion ; ISlr.

title: The complete works of Robert Burns:
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: Sir John Hume and Mr. Lumsden there, but nothing worth remembrance when the following circumstance is considered — I walk into Dunse before dinner, and out to Berrywell in the evening, with INIiss Ainslie — how well-bred, how frank, how good she is ! Charming Racbael ! may thy bosom never be

title: The complete works of Robert Burns:
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: Found Miss Ainslie, the amiable, the sensible,  the good-humoured, the sweet Miss Ainslie,  all alone at Berrywell.

title: The complete works of Robert Burns:
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: — Tluirsday, breakfast at Berrywell, and walk into Dunse to see a famous knife made by a cutler there, and to be presented  to an Italian prince.

title: The complete works of Robert Burns:
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: — Dine at a country inn, kept by a miller, in Earlston, the birth-place and residence of the celebrated Thomas a Rhymer — saw the ruins of his castle — come to Berrywell.

title: The complete works of Robert Burns:
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: — Mr. A. high in the praises of an African,  his house-servant — all his people old in his service — Douglas's old nurse came to Berrywell yesterday to remind them of its being his birthday.

title: The complete works of Robert Burns:
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: [" Burns had a memory stored with the finest poetical passages, which he was in the liabit of quoting most aptly in his correspondence with his friends: and he delighted  also in repeating them in tlie company of those friends who enjoyed them." These are the words of Ainslie, of Berrywell, to whom this letter is addressed.]

title: The complete works of Robert Burns:
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: Lord Buchan, instructing him to pull birks on the Yarvow, broom on the Cowden-knowes, and not to neglect to admire the ruins of Drybrugh Abbey, Burns set out on a border tour, accompanied by Robert Ainslie, of Berrywell.

title: The complete works of Robert Burns: containing his poems, songs, and correspondence.
